title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" is introduced, which includes an expansion of the deduction for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment sets limitations on the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income. For taxable year 2003, the deduction is $8,000, and for 2004 and beyond, it is $12,000. The reduction in the deduction amount is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding $65,000 ($130,000 for joint returns). The deduction for higher education expenses is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, which is calculated without certain deductions and after applying specific tax sections. Inflation adjustments apply for taxable years after a certain calendar year. Inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003 increase dollar amounts based on cost-of-living adjustments determined for the calendar year. Amounts are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50 if not already a multiple. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The definition of an eligible student is clarified, and the deduction is made permanent, with the amendments taking effect immediately. The amendments made by section 431 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, regarding deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses, will apply to payments made after December 31, 2002. SEC. 25C. INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. This section provides a credit for interest on higher education loans. The tax code allows individuals to claim a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced for taxpayers with a modified adjusted gross income exceeding $50,000 ($100,000 for joint filers). The tax code allows a credit for interest on education loans, with a maximum of $1,500. The credit is reduced for those with a modified adjusted gross income over $50,000 ($100,000 for joint filers). The income limits are adjusted for inflation annually. Dependents are not eligible for the credit. The tax code allows a credit for interest on education loans, with a maximum of $1,500, rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed for dependents. The credit is only allowed for the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. Definitions for "qualified education loan" and "dependent" are provided. No double benefit is allowed under this section. The tax code specifies rules for claiming the education loan interest credit, including denying double benefits, requiring married couples to file jointly, and determining marital status according to section 7703. The tax code specifies rules for claiming the education loan interest credit, including denying double benefits, requiring married couples to file jointly, and determining marital status according to section 7703. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred on, before, or after the date of the enactment of this Act, but only with respect to any loan interest payment due after December 31, 2002.
